sections.heading: Introduction
sections.text: Valentine’s Day is celebrated on February 14 each year with chocolates, flowers, and brightly colored cards featuring hearts, Cupids, and expressions of love. Although traditionally celebrated as a reflection of romantic love, the holiday has evolved into a more general celebration of friendship and appreciation.

sections.heading: History of the Holiday
sections.text: St. Valentine was a legendary Christian martyr killed during the persecution by Roman emperor Claudius II Gothicus. One account explains that Valentine was condemned to death for defying the emperor by secretly marrying couples to spare the husbands from conscription and war.

sections.heading: Origin of the Holiday
sections.text: Valentine’s Day did not become a holiday until the 5th century, when Pope Gelasius I inaugurated a feast day. Some believe it was a replacement for the Roman festival of Lupercalia, a raucous affair associated with fertility rituals.

sections.heading: Chaucer and Romance
sections.text: It took another thousand years before the day became seen as a time for lovers. Scholars believe Geoffrey Chaucer’s poem 'The Parlement of Foules' first connected the feast day with romance, describing it as the time when birds choose their mates.

sections.heading: Modern Economics
sections.text: In 2025, spending reached $27.5 billion in the US. Popular categories include jewelry, flowers, and candy. Interestingly, 32% of Americans now buy gifts for their pets, showing how the holiday has evolved.

vocabulary.ex: The holiday has evolved into a general celebration.
